GraphCL (You et al., 2020a) Node/Edge/Feature/SubGraph Stochastic Perturbation/Masking
BGRL (Thakoor et al., 2022) Node/Edge Stochastic Perturbation/Masking

GCS (Wei et al., 2023) Graph Graph Rationalization
references: Graph augmentation aims to generate compatible, identity-maintaining positive examples of the specified graph for GCL. Despite significant advancements in data augmentation for contrastive learning within computer vision and natural language processing, directly transferring these methods to the graph domain is challenging due to the non-Euclidean, and irregular structure of graph data. Current graph augmentation strategies can be roughly divided into ruled-based and learning-based approaches, depending on whether learning is involved in the augmentation process. The graph augmentation strategies in GCL are summarized in Table 1.

S3.T2.caption: Table 2. Summary of contrastive mode for GCL. “GIC”, “CIC”, and “LIC” stand for global-level intra-scale, context-level intra-scale, and local-level intra-scale contrast, respectively. While “LGC”, “LCC”, and “CGC” represent local-global inter-scale, local-context inter-scale, context-global inter-scale contrast, respectively.
S3.T2.table:
Method Pretext Task Core Idea
GraphCL (You et al., 2020a) GIC Augmentation-based graph-level contrast
AD-GCL (Suresh et al., 2021) GIC Adversarial edge dropping
SimGRACE (Xia et al., 2022b) GIC Dual encoders
HGCL (Ju et al., 2023b) GIC Multi-scale hierarchical contrast
GCC (Qiu et al., 2020) CIC Sample ego networks; Contrast among sub-graphs
GSC (Han et al., 2022) CIC Adaptive subgraph generation
MSSGCL (Liu et al., 2023d) CIC Multi-scale subgraph sampling
GRACE (Zhu et al., 2020) LIC Use structural and attribute views
GCA (Zhu et al., 2021b) LIC Adaptive augmentation using rich priors
ASP (Chen and Kou, 2023) LIC contrast among three views
B2-sampling (Liu et al., 2023c) LIC Balanced and biased sampling
DGI (Veličković et al., 2019) LGC Contrast node and graph embeddings
MVGRL (Hassani and Khasahmadi, 2020) LGC Use graph diffusion to create structural views
CGKS (Zhang et al., 2023b) LGC Graph pyramid of coarse-grained views
SUBG-CON (Jiao et al., 2020) LCC Contrast central nodes and their adjacent subgraphs
EGI (Zhu et al., 2021c) LCC Enhance MI between structural and node embeddings
GIC (Mavromatis and Karypis, 2020) LCC Contrast nodes and their cluster embeddings
SUGAR (Sun et al., 2021a) CGC Distill subgraph patterns into a sketched graph version
BiGI (Cao et al., 2021) CGC Optimize subgraph-graph MI in bipartite graphs
MICRO-Graph (Zhang et al., 2024) CGC Employ a sampler to identify informative subgraphs
references: GCL enhances the alignment between instances with similar semantic content by leveraging various graph views at different scales. These views range from graph-level view to subgraph-level view and down to node-level view, in increasing order of granularity. We further categorize the contrastive mode into intra-scale and inter-scale contrast. To be specific, intra-scale contrast focuses on comparing two views at the same granularity, such as node versus node, maintaining consistency in scale across comparisons. Conversely, the two views in inter-scale contrast have different levels of granularity, such as node versus graph, facilitating comparisons from local (node-level) to global (graph-level) perspectives within graph contexts. The contrastive mode methods in GCL are summarized in Table 2.

S3.T3.caption: Table 3. Summary of contrastive optimization strategies for GCL.
S3.T3.table:
Method Category Core Idea
InfoNCE (Oord et al., 2018) Contrastive Method NCE-based, proved to follow InfoMax principle
GRACE (Zhu et al., 2020) Contrastive Method InfoNCE-based
GCA (Zhu et al., 2021b) Contrastive Method InfoNCE-based
GCL (Zhang et al., 2022d) Contrastive Method InfoNCE-based
ProGCL (Xia et al., 2022c) Contrastive Method InfoNCE-based
PiGCL (He et al., 2024) Contrastive Method InfoNCE-based
DGI (Veličković et al., 2019) Contrastive Method Follow InfoMax principle
JSD (IRad) (Manning and Schutze, 1999) Contrastive Method Distance-based, proved to follow InfoMax principle
SP-JSD (Hjelm et al., 2018) Contrastive Method JSD-based, replacing log function with softplus
TM (Schroff et al., 2015) Contrastive Method Distance-based, no guarantee on InfoMax
BYOL (Grill et al., 2020) Non-contrastive Method Knowledge-distillation method
BGRL (Thakoor et al., 2021) Non-contrastive Method Graph-specific extension of BYOL
Barlow Twins (Zbontar et al., 2021) Non-contrastive Method Redundancy-reduction method
VICReg (Bardes et al., 2021) Non-contrastive Method Redundancy-reduction method
references: To optimize the GCL, we need to define a contrastive objective, which captures the positive samples’ similarity, while showing the negative samples’ discrepancy. Following some recent reviews on self-supervised learning strategies, we categorize the strategies into contrastive and non-contrastive methods respectively (Shwartz-Ziv and LeCun, 2023; Zhu et al., 2021b). The (Shwartz-Ziv and LeCun, 2023; Zhu et al., 2021b). The contrastive methods are those that require concrete negative samples, and the non-contrastive methods are those that can optimize without any negative samples. The contrastive optimization strategies in GCL are summarized in Table 3.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4. Summary of GCL-based weakly supervised learning methods. “HL” and “SL” are for hard and soft label utilization. Meanwhile, “IF” and “CM” are for information fusion and conflict mitigation.
S4.T4.table:
Method Category Core Idea
CG3 (Wan et al., 2021a) HL Hard guidance function for GCL
GSKN (Long et al., 2021a) HL Label-guided and kernel-based topology contrasting
HGK-GNN (Long et al., 2021b) HL Label-guided and kernel-based topology contrasting
KGNN (Ju et al., 2022b) HL Posterior regularization for label utilization
GLA (Yue et al., 2022) HL Label-invariant features for label propagation
MCL (Liu et al., 2021c) SL Memory-based prototype calculation
PCL (Lu et al., 2023) SL Transforming hard constraint to soft constraint
SimP-GCN (Jin et al., 2021a) SL Calculating soft centers with neighbors
DualGraph (Luo et al., 2022a) IF Iterative annotation and retrieval
CGPN (Wan et al., 2021b) IF Poisson Network based fusion
CoMatch (Li et al., 2021) IF Joint evolution for structure and label fusion
GAGED (Zhang et al., 2022b) CM Detecting and reducing errors
ASGN (Hao et al., 2020) CM Learning and selection
InfoGraph (Sun et al., 2019) CM Mutual information between nodes and graphs
SMGCL (Zhou et al., 2023a) CM Mutual information among multiple levels
references:
In many real-world scenarios, acquiring labeled data can be costly or impractical. In response to this challenge, Graph Weakly Supervised Learning (GWSL) has been proposed. GWSL utilizes both labeled and unlabeled data to enhance model performance in low-resource scenarios.
Current GWSL methods primarily utilize GCL to achieve two core functionalities: efficiently utilizing sparse labeled signals and fully exploiting unlabeled structural information as shown in Fig 3. The weakly supervised learning methods with GCL are summarized in Table 4.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5. Summary of graph transfer learning methods for GCL. “AL” and “DIS” are for inter-domain alignment and discrimination. Meanwhile, “TR” and “DA” are for intra-domain transferable representation learning and domain adaptation.
S4.T5.table:
Method Category Core Idea
DEAL (Yin et al., 2022a) AL Adversarial perturbations for domain alignment
UDANE (Chen et al., 2023a) AL Prototype contrastive learning
DA Consistent learning across backbones
CoCo (Yin et al., 2023a) AL Pseudo-label learning
DA Consistent learning of topologies at different levels
GCLN (Wu et al., 2022a) AL Node-and-graph contrastive learning
DA Local-and-global consistency
ACT (Wang et al., 2023b) DIS Contrastive learning by neighborhood information
GDN (Ding et al., 2021) DIS Detection of abnormal set
GCC (Qiu et al., 2020) TR Graph sampling for augmentation
SOGA (Zhu et al., 2023) TR Zero-mlps for target information learning
EGI (Zhu et al., 2021c) TR Contrastive learning across k-hop ego-graphs
CICG (Chen et al., 2022) TR Invariant subgraphs detection with information bottleneck
GraphCL (You et al., 2020a) DA Maximize mutual information with augmented views
ALEX (Yuan et al., 2023a) DA Noise-robust contrastive learning by SVD
references: Contrastive learning (CL) can improve graph transfer learning from the two aspects: inter-domain and intra-domain, as shown in Figure 4. For inter-domain, CL effectively aligns or discriminates between domains. For intra-domain, CL facilitates extracting transferable graph features that are invariant to domain shifts in the source domain, while allowing the model to learn adaptive features in the target domain. The graph transfer learning methods with GCL are summarized in Table 5.
